importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating the most recent update and context of the Mariners' failure to reach the World Series.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The current year in which the Seattle Mariners fell short of a World Series appearance, marking a pivotal moment in franchise history.

keyTakeAways: The Seattle Mariners, despite reaching the American League Championship Series (ALCS), narrowly lost to the Toronto Blue Jays in a decisive 4-3 game, missing their first-ever World Series appearance.
Cal Raleigh, a team MVP candidate, expressed deep emotional pain and described the loss as a 'failure,' highlighting the emotional toll on players and fans.
The Mariners have never appeared in a World Series in their 49-season history, making this near-miss historically significant and painful.
Julio Rodríguez, a key player, shared the team's collective disappointment, emphasizing that the effort and sacrifice were real even in defeat.
Fans expressed profound heartbreak, noting that the team's journey from being outside playoff contention early in September to reaching the ALCS was a testament to their growth and potential.
The Mariners had a promising lead in the ALCS, going 2-0 and then 3-2, with a major highlight being Cal Raleigh’s fifth postseason homer in the fifth inning.
The game loss in Game 7 at Toronto’s Rodgers Centre was decisive, as George Springer’s three-run homer in the seventh inning shifted momentum and ended the team’s hopes.
The team’s long-term contracts with Cal Raleigh and Julio Rodríguez suggest a commitment to sustained competitiveness and future World Series aspirations.
Manager Dan Wilson emphasized that the experience of reaching such close to the World Series has set a new benchmark for future goals, reinforcing ambition for the next season.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Seattle Mariners, in a heart-wrenching 4-3 loss to the Toronto Blue Jays in Game 7 of the American League Championship Series, narrowly missed their first-ever World Series appearance, maintaining their record as the only MLB team never to have reached the Fall Classic. The loss deeply affected players like MVP candidate Cal Raleigh and Julio Rodríguez, who expressed emotional pain and a sense of failure. Fans, including podcast hosts Ari and Hayley, echoed the disappointment, noting how the team’s late-season rise was a testament to their potential. Despite a strong postseason run—including a 3-1 lead with Cal Raleigh’s home run—the Mariners were undone by George Springer’s three-run homer in the seventh inning. The event marks a painful milestone in franchise history, but team leaders and players have reaffirmed the ambition to reach the World Series in the future.
title: It’s a failure: Seattle Mariners feel the deep pain of disappointment after narrowly missing out on first World Series appearance
